journal-meta.journal-title: The American Journal of Sports Medicine

title-group.article-title: Ability to Return to Sports 5 Years After Matrix-Associated Autologous Chondrocyte Transplantation in an Average Population of Active Patients

article-meta.aff: †Department of Traumatology, Medical University of Vienna, Vienna, Austria
§Norwegian Research Center for Active Rehabilitation, Norwegian School for Sport Sciences, Oslo, Norway
Investigation performed at Medical University of Vienna, Vienna, Austria, as partner of the Austrian Cluster of Tissue Regeneration

author-notes.corresp: *Lukas Zak, MD, Medical University of Vienna, Department of Traumatology, Waehringer Guertel 18-20, 1090 Vienna, Austria (e-mail: lukas.zak@meduniwien.ac.at).

permissions.copyright-holder: American Orthopaedic Society for Sports Medicine

sec.title: Background:
sec.p: Cartilage injuries often occur during sports activities, and return to sports after cartilage surgery is an important outcome parameter for different treatment methods in the competitive as well as the recreationally active population.

sec.title: Hypothesis:
sec.p: At the time of midterm follow-up after matrix-associated autologous chondrocyte transplantation (MACT), return to recreational sports at the preinjury level will be possible.

sec.title: Study Design:
sec.p: Case series; Level of evidence, 4.

sec.title: Methods:
sec.p: Seventy patients (51 men, 19 women; age [mean ± standard deviation], 34.9 ± 8.6 y; range, 18-55 y) were clinically evaluated 5 years after MACT through subjective clinical scores such as the Knee Injury and Osteoarthritis Outcome Score (KOOS) sport and recreation subscales, the Tegner activity scale, and the Noyes sports activity rating scale. The level of sports participation was included in the investigation.

sec.title: Results:
sec.p: The results 5 years after MACT showed mean values of 60.1 for the KOOS–sport, 67.4 for the Noyes, and 3.8 for the Tegner scores, meaning that regular sports activity such as cycling or running on flat ground, as well as medium-level manual labor, is possible. We noted that 74.3% of our patients returned to at least their preinjury sports level.

sec.title: Conclusion:
sec.p: Midterm postoperative results after MACT show that in a moderately active population, participation in regular sports is possible for most patients, at least at their preinjury recreational level and intensity, and there is a good rate of return to sports.

body.p: Chondral lesions of the knee joint are common after injuries5 and can limit activity in both recreational and elite athletes.14 The increasing number of active participants in recreational sports, and the number of participants in competitive sports in particular,20 have led to an increasing number of cartilage defects in the knee joint.6,8,21

Cartilage lesions have a low ability to heal on their own.4 Untreated, they can lead to chronic joint diseases and sports disability.21 Different procedures for cartilage repair have been developed, such as microfracture (MFX),28 osteochondral transplantation (OCT),12 and autologous chondrocyte transplantation.3 The goal of treatment is indeed symptom-free living, but in the active population, a return to preinjury activity level is expected6 and often defines the outcome of a surgical treatment procedure.20 Management of chondral injuries in young athletes remains a big challenge,19 and the choice of treatment requires extensive experience in cartilage repair.

Matrix-associated autologous chondrocyte transplantation (MACT) is a cartilage regeneration technique that is common in the treatment of large isolated cartilage defects and has shown good long-term results.25 In comparison with other treatment options, MACT leads to a comparable return to sports participation; MACT requires a longer time to return to sports but provides better durability in sports performance.20

Regular physical training can improve long-term results after autologous chondrocyte transplantation,16 and patients who resume training have better clinical outcomes than patients who undertake infrequent sports activity.

Many studies have been carried out to investigate the return to sports in athletes after cartilage repair procedures,9,13,20,22,23 but little is known about moderately active patients and their return to sports after MACT. The aim of this study was to evaluate a recreational sports population in terms of ability to participate in sports and changes in activity levels in 5 years after MACT.

sec.title: Patients
sec.p: We included 70 patients (51 men, 19 women) with a mean age of 34.9 years (standard deviation, ±8.6; range, 18-55), who were evaluated preoperatively and at 1, 2, and 5 years after MACT (Figure 1). The inclusion criteria for MACT surgery were set according to the recommendations of the joined advisory board of the German Societies of Traumatology and Orthopaedic Surgery regarding indications for and application of autologous chondrocyte transplantation.1

caption.p: Patient flowchart. TKR, total knee replacement; Tx, transplantation.

sec.p: Excluded from MACT were patients younger than 50 years; patients with body mass index >20% over normal; patients with uncorrected axis deformity >5°; patients who had total or subtotal meniscal resection; patients who were pregnant; and patients with severe neurologic disorders, metabolic arthritis, joint infection, tumor, psychiatric disease, arthrofibrosis, or autoimmune disease (Table 1).

tr.td: Symptomatic traumatic defects of articular cartilage of the knee
No restriction in number of defects

sec.p: Depending on defect location, we categorized patients into 3 groups: (1) tibiofemoral joint (TFJ)/femoral condyle (40 patients), (2) patellofemoral joint (PFJ) (15 patients), and (3) more than 1 simultaneous transplant in the same knee (2TX) (15 patients).
Patients’ demographic data are shown in Table 2.

fn.label: a
fn.p: PFJ, patellofemoral joint; SD, standard deviation; TFJ, tibiofemoral joint; 2TX, more than 1 simultaneous transplant in the same knee.

sec.p: In 44.3% of our patients, surgery on the meniscus (10 patients, 14.3%), surgery on the anterior cruciate ligament (ACL; 7 patients, 10%), surgery on 1 of the collateral ligaments (CL; 2 patients, 2.9%), or a combination of these (meniscus + ACL, 10 patients, 14.3%; meniscus + ACL + CL, 2 cases, 2.9%; others, 2 cases, 2.9%) had been performed before MACT. In 14.3% of patients, surgery was performed in combination with MACT (6 meniscal surgeries, 8.6%; 2 meniscal surgeries in combination with ACL surgery, 2.9%; 2 high tibial osteotomies [HTO] to correct alignment, 2.9%). In addition, 19.8% of patients had undergone a previous cartilage repair attempt such as MFX (3 patients, 4.3%), corrective osteotomy (HTO, 2 patients, 2.9%), shaving or refixation of cartilage (4 patients, 5.7%), MFX and HTO in combination (1 patient, 1.4%), refixation of a cartilage fragment or autologous osteochondral transplant (1 patient, 1.4%), and OCT (2 patients, 2.9%).

The preoperative duration of symptoms was also evaluated, wherein 51.5% of the patients had experienced their knee problems fewer than 12 months and 48.5% had experienced problems for more than 1 year.

Regarding the level of activity and sports, 4 patients reported no preinjury sports activity, 22 had performed sports occasionally, 37 had participated in regular recreational sports, and 7 had participated in competitive sports, which corresponds to an average level of sports and activity.

Ethical approval for this study was given by the ethics commission, and written informed consent was obtained from all patients for their surgery and postoperative follow-up (ethics committee of the Medical University of Vienna, EK-Nr. 513/2011).

sec.title: Surgical Treatment
sec.p: All patients with cartilage lesions—of traumatic origin or attributable to osteochondritis dissecans—underwent MACT at the Center for Joints and Cartilage of the Medical University of Vienna, Department of Traumatology. In a 2-step procedure, a biopsy sample was arthroscopically harvested to culture the cells and to seed them on a matrix (MACI [Genzyme, Cambridge, Massachusetts], 15 patients; HyalograftC [Fidia Advanced Biomaterials, Abano Terme, Italy], 44 patients; CaReS [Arthro Kinetics Biotechnology GmbH, Krems, Austria], 11 patients). Some 4 weeks later, an arthrotomy or mini-arthrotomy was performed to expose and abrade the defect and to inlay the transplant onto the subchondral lamina. In 12 patients with an osteochondral defect, an autologous cylinder of cancellous bone from the iliac crest was covered by the transplant. Fixation to the edge of the native cartilage was performed with fibrin glue and in most patients also with suturing.18

sec.title: Rehabilitation Protocol
sec.p: The different biomechanics of the tibiofemoral joint and the patellofemoral joint require different approaches to rehabilitation.11 Therefore, the components of the rehabilitation program such as weightbearing, range of motion, and strengthening exercise differ between patients with tibiofemoral lesions and those with patellofemoral lesions. In addition, the program is divided into 3 phases, each of which is designed to achieve certain goals and activity levels, and the achievement of the goals of one phase is mandatory to progress to the next phase. Tables 3 and 4 present the protocols in detail. Furthermore, patients with a transplant on both joints were treated individually, with restrictions on both weightbearing and motion.

caption.p: Rehabilitation Protocol for Femoral Defects Treated With Matrix-Associated Autologous Chondrocyte Transplantationa

tr.td: PWB with half body weight; gradual increase to FWB until end of this phase
Initial ROM of S 0-0-30; gradual increase to S 0-0-90 until end of this phase
Isometrics in allowed ROM; concentric work in limited arc of motion; no resistance
Concentric and eccentric work; low resistance
Progression in duration and resistance in concentric and eccentric work; correct muscle balance

fn.label: a
fn.p: FWB, full weightbearing; NWB, nonweightbearing; PWB, partial weightbearing; ROM, range of motion; S, movement in the sagittal plane; TWB, touch weightbearing.

caption.p: Rehabilitation Protocol for Patellofemoral Defects Treated With Matrix-Associated Autologous Chondrocyte Transplantationa

tr.td: PWB with half body weight and a brace fixed in S 0-0-20
Gradual increase to FWB until end of this phase; brace fixed at S 0-0-40 until the 4th week, at S 0-0-60 until the 6th week; brace not needed after this point
Initial ROM of S 0-0-30 actively and passively; gradual increase of passive motion to S 0-0-90 and active motion to S 0-0-60 until the end of this phase
Passive progression to full ROM; slow increase of active motion in ROM needed for ADLs
Isometrics in allowed ROM; concentric work in limited arc of motion; no resistance
Concentric and eccentric work; low resistance
Progression in duration and resistance in concentric and eccentric work; correct muscle balance

fn.label: a
fn.p: ADLs, activities of daily living; FWB, full weightbearing; PWB, partial weightbearing; ROM, range of motion; S, movement in the sagittal plane.

sec.title: Clinical Evaluation
sec.p: For the clinical evaluation, various sport-specific subjective scores were used that are included in the CARRERA (Cartilage Repair Registry Austria) questionnaire.17 The Knee Injury and Osteoarthritis Outcome Score (KOOS)26 consists of 5 subscales relating to pain, symptoms, activities of daily living (ADLs), function in sports and recreation, and knee-related quality of life (QL). We also evaluated the Noyes sports activity rating scale,24 grading the level and intensity of athletic activity, as well as the Tegner score,30 categorizing the activities from sick leave or disability up to participation in competitive (soccer) sports. These scores were evaluated preoperatively and at 1, 2, and 5 years after MACT surgery.

The levels of activity preinjury and 5 years after the operation were determined and then classified into categories of “no sports,” “occasional recreational sports,” “regular recreational sports,” and “competitive sports.”

sec.title: Statistical Evaluation
sec.p: The graphic display of data on a box plot graph showed an arbitrary, abnormally distributed data set, so we used nonparametric tests for our statistical evaluation. In addition to presenting descriptive data, we provide results from comparison and induction statistical tests that were performed with SPSS version 16.0 (SPSS, Chicago, Illinois) for Windows: the Kruskal-Wallis test and the Bonferroni-Holm test to compare the different location-dependent groups pairwise, the Wilcoxon signed rank test for related variables to compute differences between pre- and postoperative clinical scores, and the Spearman rho correlation as a nonparametric test. The latter compares influencing factors such as age, defect size, concomitant injuries, previous cartilage surgeries, and duration of symptoms before surgery with the clinical scores. A P value of <.05 indicated statistically significant results.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: Results are expressed as means ± standard deviations. Preoperative data showed a mean value of 24.8 ± 20.7 for the KOOS–sport, 28.2 ± 23.6 for the Noyes, and 1.6 ±1.3 for the Tegner scores, all of which had increased at the 12- and 24-month follow-ups and remained stable until the 60-month follow-up in all clinical scores, presented in Table 5 and Figures 2, 3, and 4. The descriptive results of the 5-year follow-up showed mean values of 60.1 for the KOOS–sport (TFJ, 67.4 ± 30.0; PFJ, 61.3 ± 23.0; 2TX, 39.7 ± 23.5), 67.4 for the Noyes (TFJ, 70.6 ± 22.7; PFJ, 66.7 ± 17.3; 2TX, 59.7 ± 30.1), and 3.8 for the Tegner scores (TFJ, 4.0 ± 1.6; PFJ, 4.3 ± 1.6; 2TX, 2.9 ± 1.1) (Figures 5-7).

caption.p: Clinical Results According to Test Scoresa

fn.label: a
fn.p: Values are expressed as mean ± standard deviation (range). KOOS, Knee Injury and Osteoarthritis Outcome Score.

caption.p: Values for the Knee Injury and Osteoarthritis Outcome Score (KOOS)–sport and KOOS–recreation subscales over the course of the study. *P < .05.
Values for the Noyes sports activity rating scale over the course of the study. *P < .05.
Values for the Tegner activity scale over the course of the study. *P < .05.
Group differences in the Knee Injury and Osteoarthritis Outcome Score (KOOS)–sport and KOOS–recreation subscale scores, 60 months postoperatively. *P < .05.
Group differences in the Noyes score, 60 months postoperatively.
Group differences in the Tegner score, 60 months postoperatively.

sec.p: A statistically significant improvement (P < .05) of all clinical scores was obtained when we compared the baseline data and the results of the 12-, 24-, and 60-month postoperative follow-ups. Furthermore, the comparisons of the location-classified data were statistically significant (P < .05) in the Bonferroni post hoc test for the KOOS–QL, KOOS–pain, KOOS–sport, and KOOS–ADL subscales between the TFJ and the 2TX group, with better results in the TFJ group (also shown in Figure 5). We could not find any statistically significant difference between the PFJ and the TFJ groups or between the PFJ and the 2TX groups.

At the 5-year postoperative follow-up, the KOOS–sport subscale showed a correlation between age and scores, with better results in the younger population, but we could not find any other statistically significant relationship between the outcome scores and the demographically related parameters, including defect size, concomitant or previous injuries or surgeries, previous cartilage surgeries, or the duration of symptoms (P > .05).

After performing the same comparisons only within the athletic population (n = 44), which included all patients who participated in regular recreational or competitive sports, we found the following statistically significant correlations: younger patients showed a better KOOS–sport and a higher preoperative sports level, smaller transplant size, shorter duration of symptoms, and higher levels of sports activity.

The comparison of levels of activity in all patients before injury and 5 years after MACT suggested that 54.3% had remained at their original level, 20% had increased their activity, and 25.7% had decreased it, which means that 74.3% returned at least to their preinjury level of sports. Even a separate evaluation of patients older than 40 years (14 patients) showed similar results (50% remained, 21% increased, and 29% decreased).

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: The MACT is an applicable and, indeed, attractive option for the treatment of cartilage lesions in athletes and active patients. Before being injured, our patients had been involved in sports on average at a midrecreational level with occasional sports activity. As the Tegner score shows, regular sports activity such as running, cycling, and cross-country skiing was possible at least twice a week for most patients—as confirmed by the results of the Noyes sports activity rating scale. As for daily living, medium labor or housework could be performed without problems. The results of our various clinical scores were similar to the mid-term to long-term data from other studies.7,10 Ebert et al7 assessed clinical and magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) outcomes to 5 years after MACT and found statistically significant improvements among others in all KOOS subgroups, with a mean value of 57.44 in the KOOS–sport subscale (60.1 in our study). Furthermore, Hambly10 reported in a systematic review that in 88% of studies evaluating the Tegner score after articular cartilage repair, an increase was reported. Included were 6 studies conducted after MACT, with a mean follow-up time of 27 months and a mean Tegner score of 4.6 (3.8 in our study). In comparison with other cartilage repair procedures in a published review by Mithoefer et al,20 MACT showed good to excellent results in 82% ± 7% of athletes (MFX, 67% ± 7%; OCT, 93% ± 5%) with a return to sports participation of 67% ± 17% (MFX, 66% ± 6%; OCT, 91% ± 3%). The time to return to sports was, at 18 ± 4 months, somewhat longer compared with outcomes of the alternative surgical techniques (MFX, 8 ± 1 months; OCT, 7 ± 2 months), but MACT has a slightly better rate of return to sports at the same level (71% ± 12%; MFX, 68% ± 5%; OCT, 70% ± 3%) and has the best results in terms of sports performance.20 Thus, MACT has advantages over the other surgical options, certainly 5 years after surgery, despite the longer rehabilitation period.

The influence of the preinjury level on functional outcome after cartilage repair is discussed controversially in the literature. Mithoefer et al,22,23 Kreuz et al,16 Blevins et al,2 and Knutsen et al15 reported better clinical outcomes for more active patients, whereas Van Assche et al31 could not find a correlation and attributed this to the different durations of preoperative symptoms. Nonetheless, about 74% of our patients returned to at least the same level of activity as before injury, and the literature similarly describes mean rates of return to sports of 67% (±17%; range, 33%-96%)20 and 78% (range, 25%-100%).13

Cartilage injuries can be isolated or can appear in combination with ligament and/or meniscal derangement.14 Other authors have reported that in a group of athletes, those who had undergone both cartilage repair procedure and prior surgeries (for ligament/meniscal repair) experienced a lower rate of return to sports.22,23 Our analysis does not verify this. There was no statistically significant difference in the clinical evaluation between the patients who had undergone prior surgery, whether they were cartilage-specific surgeries or arthroscopic surgeries of diverse natures. Moreover, the number of previous or combined surgeries such as meniscal repair, high tibial osteotomy, ACL reconstruction, or a combination of these had no influence on the outcome in our patient population. However, despite the surgeries performed, all patients met our strict inclusion criteria for MACT. Meniscal repair was done only partially (no more than one-third of the meniscal tissue) and we would have excluded from MACT therapy any patient with a symptomatic knee caused by previous ACL reconstruction.

Mithoefer et al22,23 have shown in their studies that the duration of symptoms influences the clinical outcome and the rate of return to sports in an athletic population. In our study, no differences could be shown using the same classification (<12 or >12 months of symptom duration). Furthermore, other authors mention age-related differences, whereby younger patients had better results, with a threshold to return to sports between 25 and 40 years.20 We also noted the age correlation in the KOOS–sport subscale, but sports level as well as development of sports level was similar in the age group greater than 40 years old. Contrary to our inclusion and exclusion criteria, we included 4 patients with an age greater than 50 years who were active and athletic; their biological age was obviously less 50 years.

Regarding influencing factors, female sex is a common risk factor for osteoarthritis,29 and women have an increased risk of full-thickness cartilage defects after “untreated” ACL injuries.27 However, the groups in our study had very different distributions of the sexes, so their statistical evaluation lacks explanatory ability. For this reason we did not include sex comparisons in our study.

We couldn’t find any statistically significant difference between the PFJ and the TFJ groups. This compares with the information contained in the review by Harris et al,13 where location of intra-articular defects did not predict better outcomes after any of the analyzed surgical techniques. The differences in the investigation of our patient population resulted in the comparison between single transplant on the femoral condyle and multiple transplants, with significantly worse results in the group with more than 1 transplant, which can be explained by the larger defect size and an adapted rehabilitation protocol that must apply to both joints of the knee. Nonetheless, defect size in itself did not influence the clinical results with any statistical significance.

Rehabilitation through an adequate program is crucial to optimize the results of cartilage repair surgery6 and is one of the most important influencing factors in getting patients back not only to activities of daily living and work but also to the sports activities they desire at the levels they desire. A range of protocols have therefore been published and compared, with similar clinical and radiologic outcomes.33

Limitations of this study include the retrospective character of the study, the differences in the size of patient groups, and the sole use of subjective clinical data. Another limitation is that possible postoperative influencing factors were not included in this study; for example, we do not know whether the knee treatment was the only reason why sports activity and symptoms changed in comparison with preoperative data. Some patients may choose, for whatever reason, to modify their sports habits over the years. The reason for increasing or reducing sports activity is individual to each patient and is not always directly associated with the functions and symptoms of the knee joint. Hence, impairment of activity is not always equitable with the failure rate for this treatment technique. This is particularly true in a recreationally active population compared with professional athletes. Whatever the case may be, the results of our study will provide surgeons with information to discuss with patients during the preoperative informed consent process.

In future studies, evaluation and comparison of the long-term morphologic and biochemical MRI measurements could be interesting, not only in the short term as an additional parameter for steering postoperative rehabilitation but also in the long term to compare morphologic results after MACT with the clinical results,14,32 with a view to determining whether MRIs can become predictors (leading indicators) of clinical results.

We conclude that most patients are able to engage in regular sports activity 5 years after MACT, at least at a recreational level, showing it to be a good option in the treatment of cartilage defects in the active population.

fn.p: One or more of the authors has declared the following potential conflict of interest or source of funding: The study was funded by the research budget of the Department of Trauma Surgery, Medical University of Vienna.
